questions.text: The creatinine clearance of a 27-year-old female was 80 mL/min. Hence, the GFR was found to be reduced. Which of the following factors reduce the GFR?
questions.solution:
Option D: The GFR is proportional to the renal blood flow

The blood flow is determined by:

Option A: EDRF or Nitric oxide EDRF(Endothelium Derived relaxing factor) is a vasodilator produced by endothelial cells. It works to relax vascular smooth muscle, causing dilation of blood vessels, including the afferent arterioles of the glomerulus decreases renal vascular resistance and increases GFR.

Option B: Prostaglandins also cause vasodilation of the afferent arteriole, leading to an increase in renal blood flow thus, decrease renal vascular resistance and increase GFR.

Option C: In pregnancy, the blood volume increases so, GFR is also increased.

Option D: Endothelin is a Vasoconstrictor, which constricts the renal artery and reduces the blood flow, decreasing the GFR. Potent vasoconstrictor effect occurs via ETA receptors.

Key takeaways:

Endothelin is a potent vasoconstrictor that constricts the renal artery, leading to decreased renal blood flow and a subsequent reduction in GFR. The other options (EDRF, prostaglandins, and pregnancy) all contribute to increased GFR by promoting vasodilation or increasing blood volume.

choices.text: Increased renin secretion and increased afferent arteriolar resistance
Decreased renin secretion and decreased afferent arteriolar resistance
Increased renin secretion and decrease afferent arteriolar resistance
Decrease renin secretion and increased afferent arteriolar resistance

questions.text: The macula densa is a specialised group of epithelial cells in the distal tubules of the nephron. It a part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus. A decrease in NaCl at the macula densa would cause which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: In response to low GFR, the macula densa acts as an auto regulator and increases the GFR. Decreased GFR decreases the flow in the tubule, which allows for more sodium reabsorption. This decreases the NaCl at macula densa. This causes the release of renin, which increases angiotensin II which in turn increases the efferent arteriolar resistance, ultimately increasing the GFR.

A decrease in afferent arteriolar resistance allows more blood in the glomerular capillaries and thus increases the hydrostatic pressure in them. An increased hydrostatic pressure increases the filtration and thus the GFR.

Option A: Increased renin secretion and increased afferent arteriolar resistance: Incorrect, as decreased NaCl actually leads to decreased afferent arteriolar resistance.

Option B: Decreased renin secretion and decreased afferent arteriolar resistance: Incorrect, since a decrease in NaCl triggers an increase in renin secretion.

Option D: Decreased renin secretion and increased afferent arteriolar resistance: Incorrect, as decreased NaCl causes increased renin secretion rather than decreased.

Key takeaways:

Decreased NaCl at the macula densa increases renin secretion and decreases afferent arteriolar resistance, enhancing glomerular filtration.

choices.text: Decreased GFR with decreased Na excretion
Increased GFR with normal Na excretion
Decreased GFR with normal Na excretion
Increased GFR with increased Na excretion

questions.text: An athlete of 26 years visits his family doctor for regular checkup. When asked about his diet habits, he told that he has a diet rich in meat proteins. Which of the following would reflect his GFR?
questions.solution:
Option B: A high-protein meal releases into the blood amino acids, which are reabsorbed in the proximal tubules. Because amino acids and sodium are reabsorbed together by cotransport in the proximal tubules, increased amino acid reabsorption also stimulates sodium reabsorption. This increased reabsorption of sodium decreases sodium delivery to the macula densa, which elicits a tubuloglomerular feedback-mediated increase in GFR, allowing Na excretion to remain normal with increased excretion of waste products of protein metabolism.

Option A: Decreased GFR with decreased Na excretion: Incorrect, as a protein-rich diet typically leads to increased GFR, not a decrease.

Option C: Decreased GFR with normal Na excretion: Incorrect, as increased protein intake generally increases GFR rather than decreases it.

Option D: Increased GFR with increased Na excretion: Incorrect, while GFR may increase, sodium excretion often remains normal as the kidneys regulate sodium balance in response to dietary changes.

Key takeaways:

A protein-rich diet increases GFR due to enhanced renal blood flow while sodium excretion typically remains normal.

choices.text: Urine output will be increased with high sodium concentration

questions.text: A 35 year old male has just undergone surgery for treatment of inguinal hernia. As postoperative measures, he was prescribed NSAIDs. What would be the effect on patient's urine output?
questions.solution:
Option B: After surgery, the administration of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as aspirin that inhibit prostaglandin synthesis may cause significant reductions in GFR. As it antagonizes the vasodilator effect of PGs. A decrease in vasodilation increases the renal artery resistance and hence the reduction in GFR is seen.

Option A: Urine output will be increased: Incorrect; NSAIDs reduce GFR, leading to decreased urine output.

Option C: Urine output will be normal: Incorrect; NSAIDs typically decrease urine output due to lower GFR.

Option D: Urine output will be increased with high sodium concentration: Incorrect; NSAIDs decrease urine output, not increase it.

Key takeaways:

NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, which reduces renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate (GFR), leading to decreased urine output.

questions.text: The blood flow to kidney greatly exceeds the need. This is to supply enough plasma for the higher rates of glomerular filtration that a necessary for precise regulation of the body fluid. In a 70 KG, operate how much blood flows to the kidney in a minute.
questions.solution:
Option A: The kidneys constitute only 0.4% of the total body weight but the blood supply to it is approximately 25% of the cardiac output. The normal cardiac output being roughly 5L in an average adult man, approximately 1L blood flows through the kidneys.

Renal blood flow can be measured with electromagnetic or other types of flow meters, or it can be determined by applying the Fick's principle.

It is by measuring the amount of a given substance taken up per unit of time and dividing this value by the arteriovenous difference for the substance across the kidney.

The renal plasma flow (RPF) equals the amount of a substance excreted per unit of time divided by the renal arteriovenous difference.

RPF can be measured by infusing p-aminohippuric acid (PAH) and determining its urine and plasma concentrations.

From above explanation option B, C and D are not correct.

questions.text: In a 35-year-old, man there is increase in the level of glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Which of the following component of juxtaglomerular apparatus is responsible for feedback control of GFR?
questions.solution:
Option C: Macula densa is considered as GFR sensor. Macula densa is seen where ascending limb of loop of Henle ends and distal convoluted tubule begins.

Option A: Lacis cell: Incorrect; lacis cells (or extraglomerular mesangial cells/polkissen cells) provide structural support but do not directly regulate GFR.

Option B: JG cells: Incorrect; juxtaglomerular (JG) cells release renin in response to signals from the macula densa but are not the primary sensors for GFR feedback.

Option D: Polkissen cell: Polkissen cell is other name for mesangial cell these are specialized renal cells surrounding the glomerulus, thought to play a role in renal blood flow regulation, but their function is not well-defined compared to the macula densa.

Key takeaways:

The macula densa functions as a sensor for sodium chloride concentration and plays a crucial role in feedback control of GFR by signaling to the juxtaglomerular (JG) cells to regulate renin release.

questions.text: Urine examination was done for 38-year-old man and glucose was found to be positive in the urine of the pateint although the blood glucose concentration was normal. He was diagnosed with Isolated renal glycosuria. Mutation is taking place in which channel protein in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: In Isolated, renal glycosuria there is mutations in the sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) gene (SLC5A2). Renal Glycosuria is failure of the kidneys to reabsorb glucose. In renal glycosuria, the blood glucose concentration may be normal, but the transport mechanism for tubular reabsorption of glucose is greatly limited or absent. Consequently, despite a normal blood glucose level, large amounts of glucose pass into the urine each day.

Option A: SGLT-1: This transporter primarily functions in the intestine, not in renal glucose reabsorption.

Option C: GLUT-1: This is a facilitative glucose transporter responsible for glucose transport into cells but is not directly involved in renal reabsorption.

Option D: GLUT-4: This insulin-dependent transporter is primarily found in adipose tissue and muscle, playing a role in glucose uptake but not in the kidney's glucose reabsorption.

Key takeaways:

In isolated renal glycosuria, mutations affect SGLT-2, responsible for glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, while SGLT-1, GLUT-1, and GLUT-4 are involved in other tissues or functions.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was given Aliskiren for the treatment of hypertension. Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor (DRI). Which of the following store renin?
questions.solution:
Option C: Juxtaglomerular cells (JG cells) are also called granular cells. The granules present in JG cell store renin. The JG cells are modified smooth muscle cells located mainly in the walls of the afferent arterioles immediately proximal to the glomeruli. Pressure-sensitive baroreceptors in the JG cells respond to decreased arterial pressure with increased release of renin. Increased sympathetic nervous system activity stimulates renin release by activating beta-adrenergic receptors in the JG cells.

Option A: Macula densa: These cells sense sodium chloride concentration in the distal tubule but do not store renin.

Macula densa helps in tubulo-glomerular balance.

Option B: Polkissen cell/extra glomerular mesangial cells/lacis cells/Goormaghtigh cells: These are modified smooth muscle cells involved in renal blood flow regulation but do not store renin.

Option D: Both option b and d are same.

Key takeaways:

Juxtaglomerular cells (JG cells) store renin and are modified smooth muscle cells in the afferent arterioles, responding to low blood pressure and sympathetic stimulation to release renin.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is suffering from hypertension for which he is given hydrochlorthiazide belonging to thiazide group of diuretic. This drug will act on which segment of the renal tubule?
questions.solution:
Option D: The thiazide diuretics, which are widely used to treat disorders such as hypertension and heart failure, inhibit the sodium-chloride co-transporter. It acts on this cotransporter in the distal tubules.

Option A: Proximal convoluted tubule: Thiazide diuretics do not act here; they primarily affect the distal convoluted tubule. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors act here.

Option B: Collecting duct: This segment is targeted by potassium-sparing diuretics, not thiazides.

Option C: Ascending loop of Henle: Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) act here, whereas thiazides do not.

Key takeaways:

Thiazide diuretics, like hydrochlorothiazide, act on the distal convoluted tubule, inhibiting the sodium-chloride co-transporter.

questions.text: In a 40-year-old man, there is chronic Na+ loss in the urine, with resultant hypovolemia, hypokalaemia and alkalosis due to defective transport in the thick ascending limb. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle has Na+ 2Cl - K+ co transporter that cotransports one Na+, one K+, and 2Cl- from the tubular lumen into the tubular cells. Na K ATPase in the basolateral membrane of the cell, transports Na+ out of the cell into the interstitium. Cl- exits in basolateral CIC-Kb channels. Barttin, a protein in the cell membrane, is essential for normal CIC-Kb function. K+ moves from the cell to the interstitium and the tubular lumen by ROMK (renal outer medullary potassium channel) and other K+ channels.

Bartter syndrome is due to defective transport in the thick ascending limb. It is characterized by chronic Na+ loss in the urine, with resultant hypovolemia causing stimulation of renin and aldosterone secretion without hypertension, plus hyperkalemia and alkalosis. The condition can be caused by loss-of-function mutations in the gene for any of four key proteins: The Na-K-2Cl cotransporter, the ROMK K+ channel, the ClC-Kb Cl- channel, or barttin, a recently described integral membrane protein that is necessary for the normal function of ClC-Kb Cl- channels.

Option A: Liddle syndrome: Caused by mutations leading to increased sodium reabsorption(ENaC) in the distal nephron, resulting in hypertension and hypokalemia, not hypovolemia.

Option C: Gitelman syndrome: Characterized by hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to a defect in the thiazide-sensitive Na-Cl cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule, not the thick ascending limb.

Option D: Dent syndrome: A rare X-linked disorder associated with low molecular weight proteinuria, hypercalciuria, and renal stones, not primarily characterized by chronic Na+ loss or hypovolemia.

Key takeaways:

Bartter syndrome is due to defective sodium transport in the thick ascending limb, causing chronic Na+ loss, hypovolemia, hypokalemia, and alkalosis.
